title: In Japanese, how do I write 'i will fight for you'? - Quora

response.answer_text: I would say 君のため、命をかける (きみのため、いのちをかける) Kimi is a more informal word for “you”, usually used among friends, and can also be used as an endearing term towards a significant other (the only time you will hear あなた anata is when a woman says it to her husband. Only then does it carry the meaning of “dear”). Also 命をかける (inochi wo kakeru) means “to risk one's life”. The “fight” in your sentence obviously signifies that there's risk involved, even if the speaker's life isn't necessarily in danger. It's a pretty direct phrase, so I wouldn't go about using it unless you're running an inner monologue or talking to someone dear.

あなたのために戦う Anata no tame ni tatakau あなたのために means “for your sake” or “for you” 戦う means “to fight”, you could also use 戦います The “I” can be omitted as you are the one saying it, but if you’d like: 私はあなたのために戦う 私は means “I”
